turns.content: solve this riddle: a guy with 25 horses has to determine the fastest three, he can race them agains each other, but only five at a time, how often does he have to race them?

To determine the fastest three horses out of 25, the guy can follow these steps:

1. Divide the 25 horses into five groups of five horses each.
2. Race the horses within each group, which will give us the fastest horse in each group.
3. Race the five fastest horses from the previous races against each other. The top three horses from this race will be the three fastest horses overall.

Therefore, the guy needs to conduct 7 races in total: 5 races for each group of horses, and 2 additional races to determine the fastest horses out of the winners of each group race.
But what if for instance the number two horse of the first group is faster than the number one horse of the second group?

That's a great point. In the scenario you described, simply racing the five fastest horses from the initial races against each other might not necessarily give us the three fastest horses overall. We need to make sure that we compare all 25 horses in a fair and systematic way to identify the three fastest horses.

To do this, we can modify the approach slightly. We can have each horse race in at least one heat against every other horse. This way, we ensure that all horses are compared against each other and we can determine the three fastest horses overall.

Here's how the modified approach would work:

1. Divide the 25 horses into five groups of five horses each.
2. Race all the horses in each group against each other. This will give us five races, with each horse racing once.
3. Identify the fastest horse from each group. We now have five horses that are the fastest in their respective groups.
4. Race the five fastest horses from the previous races against each other. The top three horses from this race will be the three fastest horses overall.

So the guy needs to conduct a total of six races in this modified approach. While it may take more races than the initial approach, this approach ensures that all horses are compared against each other, and we can identify the three fastest horses with confidence.

To account for the possibility that the second-fastest horse in one group may be faster than the fastest horse in another group, we can modify the approach even further. Here's an approach that ensures that every horse competes against every other horse in a total of 7 races:

1. Divide the 25 horses into 5 groups of 5 horses each.
2. Race the horses within each group, which will give us the order of finish for each horse in that group.
3. Take the top three horses from each group (i.e., the horses that finished 1st, 2nd, and 3rd in each group race) and race them against each other. The top three horses from this race will be the top nine horses overall.
4. Take the top two horses from the previous race and the next two fastest horses overall (i.e., horses that finished 4th or 5th in the first set of group races but are not in the top three from their respective groups) and race them against each other. The top three horses from this race will be the top 12 horses overall.
5. Take the top two horses from the previous race and the next two fastest horses overall (i.e., horses that finished 6th or 7th in the first set of group races but are not in the top three from their respective groups) and race them against each other. The top three horses from this race will be the top 15 horses overall.
6. Take the top two horses from the previous race and the next two fastest horses overall (i.e., horses that finished 8th or 9th in the first set of group races but are not in the top three from their respective groups) and race them against each other. The top three horses from this race will be the top 18 horses overall.
7. Take the top two horses from the previous race and the next two fastest horses overall (i.e., horses that finished 10th or 11th in the first set of group races but are not in the top three from their respective groups) and race them against each other. The top three horses from this race will be the top 21 horses overall.

At this point, we know the 21 fastest horses overall. We can determine the fastest three by taking the top two horses from the previous race and the next two fastest horses overall and racing them against each other. The top three horses from this final race will be the three fastest horses overall.

This approach ensures that every horse competes against every other horse, and we can be confident that we've identified the three fastest horses from the group of 25 in a total of 12 races.

i.e. A1, B1, C1, D1 and E1 will run the 6th race.

Phase 3 : This is the most critical part, because we have to decide which horses should run the last race. The top three horses in Race 6 will decide which horses will run this last race. Let us assume A1 came first, B1 came second and C1 came third. Hence, the last race will be between
A2, A3, B1, B2, C1
